sen.j: 日本曹洞宗の開祖である道元が、1231年から示寂する1253年まで生涯をかけて著した87巻（＝75巻＋12巻）に及ぶ大著であり、日本曹洞禅思想の神髄が説かれている。
sen.e: This is a voluminous book written by Dogen, the founder of Nihon Soto sect (Soto sect in Japan), throughout his life, from 1231 to 1253 when he died, and consisting of 87 volumes (75 volumes + 12 volumes), includes the essence of the philosophy of Nihon Soto sect.

This is a voluminous book written by Dogen, the founder of the Nihon Soto sect (Soto sect in Japan), over a large period of his life, from 1231 to his death in 1253, which consists of eighty-seven volumes (seventy-five volumes, plus a further twelve volumes), and includes the essence of the philosophy of the Nihon Soto sect.

This is a voluminous book written by Dogen, the founder of the Nihon Sotoshu sect (Sotoshu sect in Japan), over a large period of his life, from 1231 to his death in 1253, which consists of eighty-seven volumes (seventy-five volumes, plus a further twelve volumes), and includes the essence of the philosophy of the Nihon Sotoshu sect.

sen.j: 道元は、中国曹洞宗の如浄の法を継いだが、さらに道元独自の思想深化発展がなされている。
sen.e: Although succeeding the principle of Nyojo in the Soto sect in China, Dogen advanced the philosophy to a higher level by himself.
Although assuming the principles of Nyojo of the Soto sect in China, Dogen advanced the philosophy to a higher level.
Although assuming the principles of Nyojo of the Sotoshu sect in China, Dogen advanced the philosophy to a higher level.

sen.j: また、鎌倉時代の仏教者の主著が全て漢文で書かれている（法然、親鸞『教行信証』、栄西、日蓮、…）時代に、真理を正しく伝えたいという考えから日本語、仮名で著述している。
sen.e: Furthermore, though all major manuscripts of Buddhist priests were written in Chinese characters (such as those of Honen, "Kyogyoshinsho" (Teaching, Practice, Faith, and Enlightenment) by Shinran, those of Eisai, of Nichiren, etc), he made the descriptions in Japanese, or Kana, so that truth could be understood more correctly.

In addition, though all major manuscripts by Buddhist priests were written in Chinese characters, such as those of Honen, "Kyogyoshinsho" (Teaching, Practice, Faith, and Enlightenment) by Shinran, and those of Eisai and Nichiren among others, he made the descriptions in Japanese Kana so that the truth could be understood more accurately.

In addition, though all major manuscripts by Buddhist priests were written in Chinese characters, such as those of Honen, "Kyogyoshinsho" (Teaching, Practice, Faith, and Enlightenment) by Shinran, and those of Eisai and Nichiren among others, he made the descriptions in Japanese Kana so that the truth could be understood more accurately.

sen.j: 古い巻の記述を書き直し、新しい巻を追加して、全部で100巻にまで拡充するつもりであったが、87巻で病のため完成できなかった。
sen.e: He intended to write a total of 100 volumes by rewriting older ones and by adding new volumes, but died from a disease after completing the 87th volume.
He intended to write a total of one hundred volumes by rewriting older ones and adding new volumes, but died from a disease after completing the eighty-seventh volume.

sen.j: （仮字）『正法眼蔵』は、道元の禅思想を表現するために、語録から特に公案で使われてきた重要な問答を取り出し、それに説明注釈する形で教えを述べている。
sen.e: In (Kana) "Shobogenzo," to express Dogen's Zen philosophy, important question-answer dialogues, in particular, those used in koan, were picked up from goroku (descriptions of what priests said), and his philosophy was explained in the form of annotating each of the dialogues.

In the "Kana Shobogenzo" important question-answer dialogues, in particular those used in koan, were selected from goroku (descriptions of what priests said during their lives) in order to express Dogen's Zen philosophy, this philosophy being explained by annotating each of the dialogues.

In the "Kana Shobogenzo" important question-answer dialogues, in particular those used in koan, were selected from goroku (descriptions of what priests said during their lives) in order to express Dogen's Zen philosophy, this philosophy being explained by annotating each of the dialogues.

sen.j: これの種本が（真字）『正法眼蔵』であり、10種類ぐらいの禅語録から道元からみて重要な300則の禅問答を抜き出している。
sen.e: The book constituting its base was (Mana) "Shobogenzo," and Dogen picked up 300 Zen question-answer dialogues, which he considered important, from around ten pieces of goroku.
